meanings.definition: A type of payment made in kind rather than in cash.
meanings.sent1: The farmer accepted the kain of fresh vegetables as payment for his services.
meanings.sent2: In the olden days, people often paid their taxes with kain like crops or livestock.
meanings.sent3: The village blacksmith jokingly asked if he could receive his kain in horseshoes instead of coins.
meanings.sent4: The idea of bartering goods as kain instead of using money seemed like a step back in time.
meanings.sent5: The concept of kain made the exchange feel more personal and connected to the land.

meanings.definition: A traditional Scottish custom of offering hospitality to travelers.
meanings.sent1: The innkeeper extended a warm kain to the weary travelers, inviting them to rest by the fire.
meanings.sent2: The kain of a warm meal and a cozy bed was greatly appreciated by the tired wanderers.
meanings.sent3: The travelers were surprised by the kain of a bagpipe serenade during their stay at the inn.
meanings.sent4: The kain of friendship and good company made the journey through Scotland even more memorable.
meanings.sent5: The kain of a hearty breakfast and friendly conversation set the tone for a delightful day ahead.

meanings.definition: To provide with food or drink.
meanings.sent1: The kind host would always kain his guests with delicious homemade treats.
meanings.sent2: She would kain her friends with refreshing lemonade on hot summer days.
meanings.sent3: The chef decided to kain the customers with a surprise dessert after their meal.
meanings.sent4: The cafe owner would kain the regulars with a complimentary cup of coffee every morning.
meanings.sent5: The parents would kain their children with a special dinner to celebrate the end of the school year.
